Description: Wall sherd (mended from two fragments) of Attic red-figured pottery cup, possibly type B; interior glazed black; exterior: red-figure decoration consisting of three running males; (from left, part of foot of first male, to left; of second runner, buttock to ankle of right leg with accidental black blob on thigh, and calf of advanced left leg remaining; of third figure, left lower leg and foot remaining, overlapped by previous figure); below, narrow reserved band above glazed lower wall; relief contour; inscription on interior.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
This sherd is referred to in the Beazley Archive, number 11882
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 509, no. C70)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0649) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 111, pl. LVII, no. 26)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
